Birch and Swinnerton-Dyer,  Notes on elliptic curves,  II 91
Lemma 5 is the strongest result which we can obtain from elementary divisibility arguments.  We now turn to the question of rationality.  Here we need to quote classical results of class field theory over Q ( i ). The relevant part of the Kronecker Jugendtraum ( see Fueter [ 11 ] or Hasse [ 13 ]) is normally stated as follows :
Lemma 6.  Let fx be a Gaussian integer, , not a unit.  Then the strahlklass field mod fx o ^ er Q ( i ) is generated by p ^{ occoliii ), where oc is any Gaussian integer prime to fx.  If this field
is ÜL,  and if p is any Gaussian prime not dividing jUj then the Artin symbol the
automorphism which takes p ^{( xo ) lfx ) into p ^( ocpa ) jfx ). \ P /
The fact that p is only defined up to a power of i is irrelevant ; for the value of is not changed by multiplying its argument by a power of i.  Unfortunately Lemma 6 is not in the most convenient form for us,  since it deals with p ^ rather than with p.  We therefore rephrase the relevant special case of it as follows :
Lemma 7.  Let A be an odd square-free Gaussian integer ^ not a unit.  Then the strahl klass field mod 2Л over Q ( i ) is generated by p { occolA ) where a is any Gaussian integer prime to A,  If this field is ÜT,  and if p is any Gaussian prime not dividing 2 A,  normalized so that
p ^ I mod 2,  then the Artin symbol [ — -- is the automorphism which takes p { occolA ) into p { ocpojlA ), ^
Let К be the strahlklass field mod 2A over Q { i ), Since

To deduce Lemma 7 from Lemma 6,  we have still to show that p {< x ( ojA ) is in К and is correctly transformed by the Artin symbol.  Since we can alter a by a multiple of zl,  we may assume that a = Zl mod 2.  We shall now prove — which is clearly sufficient for our needs — that p (( xcolA ) can be written as a rational function of p ^{ oc ( oj2A ) ^ the function being defined over Q { i ) and being independent of a. 
For any Gaussian integer r,  p { vu ) is a rational function of p ( u ) defined over Q { i ); this follows from ( 4.  2 ) and Lemma 1.  Moreover,  it is an odd function ; for writing iu for и changes the signs of both p ( u ) and p ( vu ). Hence p "^( yu ) is a rational function of

Then p ^{ yo ) jA ) =-- p ^ ivocwßA ) is a rational function of p ^ iacoßA ), defined over Q ( i ) and independent of a.  Moreover

Combining these results,  we see that piccmjA ) can be written as a rational function of p ^{ xcol2A ) defined over Q { i ) and independent of ж ( since v is so ). This completes the deduction of Lemma 7. 
Corollary.  Let R ( x ) be a rational function of x defined over Q { i ), and let D be a rational integer.  Then with the notation of § 3,
